captions.text:
Anyone who goes fishing probably has a fishy
story about "the one that got away." It was

this big, doncha know. Yah, that was a bummer...
but it's actually quite important that big
fish get away, both for fish and fishermen.

For most of the species that we fish, commercial
and recreational fishermen are only allowed

to keep individuals above a minimum legal
size. The idea behind these laws is to protect

juveniles so they can grow big enough to reproduce
at least once before becoming our dinner.

In theory, that means there will always be
enough fish for dinner tomorrow. And insuring

dinner for tomorrow is important enough that
the British Parliament discussed protecting

young - that is, small - fish as early as
1376, and today it's a common regulation for
fisheries worldwide.
Except, it doesn't really work.

First, large individuals have the greatest
number of successful offspring both because

bigger fish produce more eggs and because
the eggs they produce ALSO contain a more

generous food supply for the baby fishies.
So by removing the largest fish of a given

species, we severely decrease the population's
ability to replenish itself.

Second, if we only remove the largest fish,
that means fish that are small for their age

- and thus smaller when they first reproduce
- are more likely to live long enough to make

babies. So individuals with small-fish genes
tend to stay in the water, reproduce, and

pass on their small-fish genes to new generations,
while big fish and big-fish genes become rarer

and rarer. We're basically breeding smaller
fish, unintentionally - and it's not a small

change. Size-selective fishing has caused
the body mass of large commercial fish to

be cut in half over the last 40 years - let
me say that again: heavily-fished fish are

now half the weight they used to be. Six-year-old
haddock, for example, weigh 40% of what they

did in 1970. Imagine if full-grown men weighed
65-pounds!

Clearly, size-selective fishing means fewer
and smaller fish in the water, which suggests

it's not the best way to keep our fish supply
stocked for future human generations. And

in fact, there's a new idea called "balanced
harvesting" ready to save the day. Instead

of reeling in all of the largest individuals,
fishermen would catch a smaller number of

fish across a wider range of sizes, keeping
the numbers and sizes of fish, well, balanced.

However, old habits die hard, and the use
of size limits is deeply ingrained in our

collective fisheries management DNA. But sooner
rather than later, we'll have to accept that

it's good to let some of the "big ones" get
away, for only they can change the course
of fishtory.

title: The One That Got Away (Size Matters)

comments.author: Tao Tao Liu

comments.text:
Hi Henry!

I have heard of the balanced harvesting method before, thought I wanted to 
share that it is one of the means of fishery management. There is another 
one popping up that I found quite interesting that involves taking the 
biggest fish, but only the biggest fish that are at the end of their 
reproductive potential.

Apparently, the rate at which fish reach the end of their reproductive 
potential are different between species and even different between 
populations. The research suggests that instead of using absolute lengths, 
fishery managers use proportions (i.e. only harvest herring when they have 
reached 75% of their full length).

Hordyk, A. et al., 2011: 
http://www.researchgate.net/publication/236651920_A_cost-effective_alternative_for_assessing_the_size_of_deep-water_fish_aggregations

Prince, J.D. 2003: 
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1467-2979.2003.00134.x/abstract;jsessionid=8B08B290E5B44590AFEC35269518DDD2.f02t03?deniedAccessCustomisedMessage=&userIsAuthenticated=false
﻿

about half the size they should be fully grown. Kinda cool how genetics 
work﻿

comments.author: Jeff Brondo

comments.text:
Evolution and selective breeding use the same process but work differently. 
Humans fish up billions of fish easily each year. And if they are literally 
only fishing up the lrgest fish then that's a massive impact to the 
population, and will leave little other choice than smaller fish to breed. 
Which is not how natural evolution would work. Natural evolution would not 
cut such a significant part of the population so quickly. It'd bee more 
gradual and on a smaller scale. Hence taking millions of years.
comments.author: David Parkes

comments.text:
It doesnt take that many years. You are using the term evolution wrong, the 
small fish already carry the genes for small offspring, and mate with other 
fish with the same genes = small fish genes are passed on. The offspring 
arent evolving to have small fish genes from large fish genes, they never 
had large fish genes in the first place.

comments.author: David Parkes

comments.text:
The difference between the two scenarios is once big fish are gone only 
little fish remain. The big fish didn't become smaller. If we only fish 
small fish, big fish will remain big. But the availability of large fish to 
reproduce with will continuously increase the size of the fish population 
until the size is normalized and we have a normal distribution of small 
fish (which are now considerably bigger from the previous "small fish") and 
large fish (which are slightly bigger than the previous "large fish"). From 
there the system will remain in equilibrium until we start injecting fish 
with growth hormones like we already do with our mainland stock.
comments.author: Ryan Shaw

comments.text:

comments.text:
The advantage of size limit to fishing don't directly hamper the amount of 
fishing you are allowed to do. This is especially important if different 
countries are fishing the same population, because just one country that 
has loser regulations can cause serious over fishing problems. While it's 
relatively simple to agree on what size of the fish is too small to be 
caught. 

It would also require active monitoring of fish population and branch of 
government which only job monitored the fish population and gave fishing 
right in amount of fish you can fish. (much with game animals) then you'd 
have to be able to enforce people not to fish too much. and negotiate with 
other countries so they too wouldn't over fish.

It might be better system, but it's not trial to implement. Especially when 
every country has economic incentive to fish fish more than their 
neighbors.﻿

comments.author: Duder

comments.text:
Geez, so much confusion in this thread. The "theory of evolution" is only a 
scientific explanation of how evolution works, in the exact same way that 
the "theory of relativity" is an explanation of how gravity works. 
Evolution is nothing more than (quoting wikipedia) "the change in the 
inherited characteristics of biological populations over successive 
generations." The theory of evolution is about how this happens, back in 
Darwin's day the best explanation for this was a concept called natural 
selection. Some concepts about it later became obsolete, and the theory has 
been polished throughout time to now include so many factors it'd be almost 
impossible to mention all of them here.
In science you don't "prove a theory," (especially since a theory already 
means "proven hypothesis") you only improve upon it. As for the things it 
explains, you can prove evolution as much as you can prove gravity, both 
are phenomena that everyone knows to happen, science only tries to explain 
them.
Also, to Mr. Campbell, there is no difference between micro-evolution and 
macro-evolution, both are changes "in the inherited characteristics" of 
species, precisely the definition of evolution. There is absolutely no 
debate on whether "macro" happens or not; the biggest extent of the debate 
in the scientific world (if anything) would be something like what plays a 
bigger role in evolution, genetic drift or genetic draft.
comments.author: Miguel Zavaleta

comments.text:
+Mike Campbell
Micro evolution and macro evolution are the same thing
There is no debate
